byline.contributor: Saw Nang contributed reporting from Mandalay, Myanmar.

abstract: Study published in British medical journal The Lancet finds Rohingya ethnic group has faced widespread discrimination in access to medical care in Myanmar and other countries in Asia, with great impact on health and mortality rates; researchers say role of Myanmar's government in humanitarian crisis makes its actions tantamount to genocide or, at very least, ethnic cleansing.

headline.print_headline: Study Finds Medical Bias Against a Muslim Group
headline.main: Rohingya Face Health Care Bias in Parts of Asia, Study Finds

keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

snippet: A report by Harvard researchers in The Lancet found that health care indicators were consistently worse for the Rohingya, a Muslim ethnic group....
lead_paragraph: A report by Harvard researchers in The Lancet found that health care indicators were consistently worse for the Rohingya, a Muslim ethnic group.
